item.title: Pyhackthon
item.description:
Pyhackthon ğŸğŸ–¥ï¸

Introduction

ğŸ‘‹ Hey Tech Enthusiasts and Cyber World Lovers!

Have you ever wondered how easy it is to evade antivirus software and code a fully functional malware tool? In today’s blog, we’ll dive deep into the world of Python and how script kiddies (those pesky noobs ğŸ˜…) use it to develop harmful tools.

More importantly, you’ll learn how to build one yourself (for educational purposes, of course!) and how to defend yourself against them. âš”ï¸

Pyhackthon: Welcome to the Dark Side of Python ğŸŒ‘

Python is a versatile, high-level programming language that is:

  • Easy to Learn ğŸ’¡
  • Easy to Code ğŸ› ï¸
  • Full of Powerful Libraries ğŸ“š

However, its flexibility has made it a favorite for cybercriminals too. They often misuse Python for creating malware that can harm systems. Today, we’re going to look into how a simple Python script can turn into a full-fledged Remote Access Trojan (RAT), and how you can protect yourself from such attacks.

RAT: The Dangerous Mouse ğŸ­ğŸ’»

No, not that kind of rat! ğŸ€ In computer terms, RAT stands for Remote Access Trojan.

Imagine receiving a harmless-looking email attachment, and when you open it, someone gains complete control of your computer without your consent! ğŸ˜± Scary, right?

A RAT is like a fox disguised as Grandma ğŸ‘µ (Trojan) but sneakierâ€”giving attackers remote access to your system to steal data, monitor your activity, and even control your files.

Disclaimer ğŸ›‘:

Misusing this tool can land you in legal troubleâ€”think late-night knock on the door kinda trouble ğŸš”. So, make sure you’re using it responsibly and ethically.

What Makes This Tool Special? ğŸ‰

  1. Easy Setup - Get it running in minutes â²ï¸
  2. No Port Forwarding Required - A hassle-free experience ğŸŒ
  3. Accessible - All you need is an internet connection and a browser ğŸŒ

ğŸ› ï¸ Setup and Installation ğŸ› ï¸

Follow these simple steps:

  1. ğŸ´ Clone This Repository: Fork it, clone it, just get it!
  2. ğŸ“¦ Install Requirements: Run the following command:
1

pip install -r requirements.txt

Requirements command

  1. âœ‰ï¸ Create a New Gmail Account: DO NOT use your personal account for this! Enter the credentials into gmail.py.

Write Creds

  1. ğŸ”“ Enable Less Secure Apps: Because we like living dangerously ğŸ˜.

  2. ğŸ“§ Configure Email: For receiving results and sending commands to YOUR_MAIL.

  3. ğŸ–¥ï¸ Convert to Executable: Use PyInstaller:

1

pyinstaller --onefile --noconsole gmail.py

Pyinstaller Command

  1. ğŸ’» Install on the Target Machine: Insert evil laugh here ğŸ˜ˆ.
  2. â³ Wait 2 Minutes: Check your email for results.
  3. ğŸ”§ Send Commands via Email: Flex those hacking muscles ğŸ’ª.
  4. ğŸ Exit Command: Send the command EXIT to stop the tool.
  5. ğŸ‰ Congratulations! You’ve created your first Python RAT.

Aftermath ğŸ­

Once you’ve run the RAT, hereâ€™s what you can do:

  • ğŸ–¥ï¸ Run Some Commands.
  • ğŸ§  Teach Others about cybersecurity risks.
  • ğŸ’ª Contribute to improving this tool by adding features.
  • ğŸŒŸ Star the Repo to show your support!

Prevention Tips ğŸš¨

Now that you know how dangerous RATs can be, hereâ€™s how to protect yourself:

  • Avoid clicking on suspicious links or opening unexpected attachments ğŸš«.
  • Hover over links before clicking to see where they really lead ğŸ”.
  • Always use antivirus software.
  • Keep your system, browser, and antivirus up-to-date ğŸ”„.
  • Never download software from untrusted or pirated sources âŒ.

Conclusion ğŸ¯

So there you have itâ€”the sneaky world of Remote Access Trojans. Always be cautious of what you click online. If something seems too good to be true, it probably is. When in doubt, ask a cyber professional.

Remember: just like your room, keep your online space locked and safe. ğŸ›¡ï¸

Share your thoughts in the comments below and feel free to connect with me on GitHub, Instagram, or Telegram for more cool content!

Thank you for visiting my blog! ğŸ˜

item.title: Flask-Phishing
item.description:
Flask-Phishing

Introduction

Hey there, fellow tech adventurers! ğŸ‰ Ready to dive into the sneaky world of phishing? Don’t worry; this is all in good fun and education. Today, weâ€™re going to explore a Python Flask phishing framework. Grab your virtual trench coat and magnifying glass, and letâ€™s go!

Phishing: The Internet’s Dark Alley ğŸ•µï¸â€â™‚ï¸

“Phishing is a major problem because there really is no patch for human stupidity.” - Mike Danseglio

What on Earth is Phishing? ğŸ¤”

Imagine getting an email from your favorite pizza place offering free pizza for a year. You click the link, and boom! Your personal info is stolen. Phishing is like thatâ€”bad guys pretending to be someone you trust to steal your information. Sneaky, huh?

Phishing is a sneaky trick where bad guys pretend to be someone you know online to steal your personal info. Imagine a wolf in sheep’s clothing, but the sheep is your favorite website. The site looks legit but is made to trick you. Always check twice before entering your info!

So, Why Should I Care? ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸

Knowing about phishing is crucial because it shows just how easy it is to fall for these tricks. But hereâ€™s the twist: weâ€™re going to use this knowledge for good. Iâ€™ll show you how to set up a phishing site (purely for educational purposes, of course).

Disclaimer: This tool is for ethical hackers only. If you’re not one of those, please go back to watching cat videos. ğŸ˜¸ Weâ€™re not responsible if you turn into a cyber villain. Use at your own risk, and remember, your mom was right about talking to strangers online. ğŸš«

What Makes This Tool Special? ğŸ‰

  • Flask-Powered: Deploy it on the web with ease.
  • No Port Forwarding: Forget the hassle of port forwarding or ngrok.
  • User-Friendly: Simple web interface that even your grandma could use (probably).
  • Accessible: Just need the internet and a web browser.

Installation on Webhosting ğŸŒ

  1. Requirements: Internet and a device (laptop recommended, but you can try your luck with a mobile phone).
  2. Deployment Platform: We’ll use PythonAnywhere.

Step-by-Step Guide ğŸš€

  1. Create an Account: Sign up on PythonAnywhere. Yes, you know how to create an account. ğŸ™„

  2. Dashboard Navigation: Head to the dashboard.

  3. Open a New Console: Click on ‘New Console’ and select ‘Bash’.

  4. Clone the Repository: Enter git clone https://github.com/siddhant385/flask-phishing in the console.

  5. Navigate to Directory: Type cd flask-phishing in the console

  6. Install Requirements: Run pip install -r requirements.txt.

  7. Open Web Tab: Go back to the dashboard and click on ‘Web’.

  1. Add New Web App: Click on ‘Add new web app’ and select ‘Flask’
  • Next Step
  • Next Step
  • Next Step
  1. Configure Path: Enter the path to your main script, e.g., /home/yourusername/flask-phishing/main.py.
  1. After you have clicked next a web dashboard will be opened scroll down and then click go to directory of Source code as given in picture below
  1. Now click on main.py
  1. Open a new tab and open this url on your new tab and click copy button as shown in the picture Url is : https://github.com/siddhant385/flask-phishing/blob/main/main.py
  1. After you have copied the code remove all the previous code written in the main.py and paste copied code there and click on save button
  1. Reload Your Site: Click on ‘Reload’ on the PythonAnywhere dashboard.
  1. Access Your Site: Go to yourusername.pythonanywhere.com. Use default credentials admin and root to log in, then change them immediately.
- You will be redirected to a new page click on config tab and change your username and password. Hence you are good to go

Congrats! ğŸ‰

You have successfully hosted your phishing site!

AftermathğŸ­

  • Create a Telegram Bot: Send usernames and passwords directly to your Telegram bot.
  • Send Links: Share links to teach others about phishing.
  • View Trapped Data: Check the DATA tab for captured info.
  • Contribute: Help improve the tool.
  • Star the Repo: Show your support for the author! ğŸŒŸ

Prevention Tips ğŸš¨

  • Avoid unexpected links or attachments.
  • Hover over links to check URLs.
  • Enable 2FA for extra security.
  • Keep your system, browser, and antivirus updated

Conclusion

So, there you have it, the lowdown on phishing. It’s like those annoying telemarketers but way sneakier. Be smart, stay alert, and don’t click on everything you see. If it sounds too good to be true, it probably is. When in doubt, ask a friend, parent, or teacher.

Remember, your online life is like your room: keep the doors locked and don’t let just anyone in. ğŸ›¡ï¸

Write your thoughts in the comments below!

Thank you for visiting my blog! I hope you find my posts interesting and informative. Feel free to connect with me on GitHub, Instagram, or via email. Your feedback and suggestions are always welcome. Stay tuned for more updates!

```
